META.prose: This map shows the three, generally accepted “migrant streams” in which farmworkers tend to travel to harvest crops seasonally. Each stream begins and ends in one of three “sending states,” Florida, Texas or California, where farmworkers will return at the end of the season. The streams are fluid, adjusting to regional shifts, with the Texas stream being the most divergent, with some workers ending up in Washington state or Florida.
META.source: U.S. Department of Health & Human Services, Migrant Head Start Program

TREE.name: Supermarkets
TREE.tooltip: SM Jones sells produce to wholesalers and supermarkets that sell it to consumers.

TREE.name: SM Jones
TREE.tooltip: SM Jones is a produce packing and transport company, they work with four partner farms to prepare and ship produce to supermarkets and wholesalers.

TREE.name: Sunrise Labor
TREE.tooltip: Sunrise Labor Corp is a farm labor contractor corporation. Their clients are farms that need workers to harvest produce. They hire contractors, like Hernandez, to recruit low wage workers, like Jimenez Luna

TREE.name: Turek Farms
TREE.tooltip: Turek Farms in Kings Ferry, NY is SM Jones partner. Jimenez Luna fled Hernandez' crew from here.

TREE.name: YCO
TREE.tooltip: Your Corporate Office Labor Corp, owned by Rusty Reaves, handled payroll and administrative tasks for Sunrise Labor

TREE.name: Salvador Hernandez
TREE.tooltip: This is Salvador Hernadez, one of several contractors working for Sunrise Labor

TREE.name: Workers Two
TREE.tooltip: This is Salvador Hernandez' crew of indebted workers. Including Juan Jimenez Luna
